level2_hover.description: Complete dimensional reduction cascade from 26D bulk to 4D observable spacetime

26D_(24,2).name: 26D Bulk

Sp(2,R).description: Sp(2,‚Ñù) gauge symmetry removing ghost states from two-time structure

G_2.description: Exceptional holonomy group for 7D compactification manifold

6D_(5,1).description: 5 spatial + 1 temporal dimension after G‚ÇÇ compactification (13D - 7D)

4D_(3,1).name: 4D Observable
4D_(3,1).description: Our 3+1 dimensional spacetime after final compactification

assumptions: Remaining 2 spatial dimensions compactify on small scale
steps: Start: Virasoro anomaly cancellation requires D=26 with signature (24,2)
Stage 1: Sp(2,‚Ñù) gauge fixing eliminates 13 DOF ‚Üí 13D shadow (12,1)
Stage 2: G‚ÇÇ compactification on 7D manifold ‚Üí 6D effective (5,1)
Stage 3: Final compactification of 2 dimensions ‚Üí 4D observable (3,1)
Result: Full cascade 26D ‚Üí 13D ‚Üí 6D ‚Üí 4D with signature preservation
derivation.comments: This is the central dimensional reduction cascade of PM. Each stage has geometric/topological origin, not ad-hoc choices.

approximations: Assumes clean decoupling between reduction stages
Neglects back-reaction from lower-dimensional physics on higher-dimensional geometry

level1_display.plain_text: [J_ab, J_cd] = i(Œ∑_ac J_bd + Œ∑_bd J_ac - Œ∑_ad J_bc - Œ∑_bc J_ad)
level1_display.label: (3.1) Sp(2,‚Ñù) Generator Commutator

level2_hover.description: Commutation relations for Sp(2,‚Ñù) gauge generators acting on two-time coordinates

J_ab.name: Sp(2,‚Ñù) Generator
J_ab.description: Symplectic group generator for gauge transformations on (t‚ÇÅ, t‚ÇÇ)

assumptions: Sp(2,‚Ñù) is the gauge group (not SO(2) or larger group)
Metric signature is (24,2) from string theory
steps: Start: Sp(2,‚Ñù) preserves symplectic form Œ© on phase space
Generators: J_ab = x_a p_b - x_b p_a (antisymmetric)
Commutator: [J_ab, J_cd] computed via Jacobi identity
Result: Standard Sp(2,‚Ñù) algebra with metric-dependent structure constants
derivation.comments: This is standard symplectic Lie algebra, adapted to (24,2) signature

sp2r-constraint-null.label: (3.1a) Null Constraint

level2_hover.description: First Sp(2,‚Ñù) constraint: position vector must be null in (24,2) signature

assumptions: Position vector lies on constraint surface
steps: Start: 26D phase space with coordinates (X^M, P^M)
Requirement: X^2 = -t‚ÇÅ¬≤ - t‚ÇÇ¬≤ + Œ£·µ¢ x·µ¢¬≤ = 0
Physical interpretation: Two time coordinates are gauge-related through spatial dimensions
Effect: Eliminates one degree of freedom from position space
Gauge orbit: Sp(2,‚Ñù) transformations preserve X¬≤ = 0 surface
derivation.comments: This constraint links two times to spatial dimensions, preventing ghost states

sp2r-constraint-null.physical_interpretation: The null constraint X¬≤ = 0 ensures that the two time coordinates cannot vary independently. Instead, they are constrained by the relation -t‚ÇÅ¬≤ - t‚ÇÇ¬≤ + |x|¬≤ = 0, which geometrically means the position vector lies on a null cone in (24,2) spacetime. This prevents causality violations that would arise from two independent time directions.

sp2r-constraint-orthogonality.label: (3.1b) Orthogonality Constraint

level2_hover.description: Second Sp(2,‚Ñù) constraint: position and momentum must be orthogonal

steps: Start: Phase space (X^M, P^M) with canonical Poisson brackets
Requirement: X¬∑P = -E‚ÇÅt‚ÇÅ - E‚ÇÇt‚ÇÇ + Œ£·µ¢ p·µ¢x·µ¢ = 0
Physical interpretation: Prevents backward-in-time energy flow
Effect: Position and momentum are orthogonal in (24,2) metric
Gauge orbit: Preserved under Sp(2,‚Ñù) transformations
derivation.comments: This constraint ensures causality by preventing negative energy states

sp2r-constraint-orthogonality.physical_interpretation: The orthogonality constraint X¬∑P = 0 prevents backward-in-time propagation. In ordinary 1-time physics, this would be automatic from energy conservation. In 2-time physics, it must be imposed as a constraint to ensure that energy flow respects causality.

sp2r-constraint-mass-shell.label: (3.1c) Mass-Shell Constraint

level1_display.html: P¬≤ = P<sup>M</sup> Œ∑<sub>MN</sub> P<sup>N</sup> = M¬≤ (mass-shell constraint)
level1_display.plain_text: P¬≤ = P^M Œ∑_MN P^N = M¬≤ (mass-shell constraint)
level1_display.label: (3.1c) Mass-Shell Constraint

level2_hover.description: Third Sp(2,‚Ñù) constraint: momentum satisfies relativistic mass-shell relation

steps: Start: Relativistic dispersion E¬≤ = p¬≤ + M¬≤ (1-time version)
Generalization: In (24,2), require P¬≤ = M¬≤ with P¬≤ = -E‚ÇÅ¬≤ - E‚ÇÇ¬≤ + |p|¬≤
Physical interpretation: Ensures positive energy via modified dispersion
Effect: Constrains energy-momentum to mass shell
Result: No ghost states (negative norm) in physical spectrum
derivation.comments: This is the Einstein dispersion relation generalized to (24,2) signature

sp2r-constraint-mass-shell.physical_interpretation: The mass-shell constraint P¬≤ = M¬≤ ensures that all physical particles satisfy a modified Einstein dispersion relation. In (24,2) signature, this becomes -E‚ÇÅ¬≤ - E‚ÇÇ¬≤ + |p|¬≤ = M¬≤, which guarantees positive energy and prevents ghost states.

level2_hover.description: Three gauge generators forming SL(2,‚Ñù) ‚âÖ Sp(2,‚Ñù) algebra

L_0.name: L‚ÇÄ Generator
L_0.description: Generator proportional to null constraint X¬≤ = 0

L_1.description: Generator proportional to orthogonality constraint X¬∑P = 0

L_{-1}.name: L‚Çã‚ÇÅ Generator

steps: Start: Three first-class constraints from Sp(2,‚Ñù) symmetry
Verify: {L_m, L_n} = (m-n)L_{m+n} under Poisson brackets
Result: Generators form SL(2,‚Ñù) ‚âÖ Sp(2,‚Ñù) Lie algebra
DOF removed: 3 constraints √ó 2 (first-class) = 6 phase space DOF
Additional: Complete gauge fixing removes 3 more DOF
Total: 26 ‚Üí 13 effective dimensions after gauge fixing
derivation.comments: The SL(2,‚Ñù) algebra structure is standard in two-time physics (Bars formalism)

2^{[13/2]}.name: Spinor Dimension Formula

steps: Start: 26D bulk with 8192-component spinor Œ®‚Çà‚ÇÅ‚Çâ‚ÇÇ ‚àà Cl(24,2)
Sp(2,‚Ñù) reduction: 26D ‚Üí 13D halves spinor dimension
Formula: dim(spinor) = 2^{[D/2]} where [x] is floor function
Calculate: 2^{[13/2]} = 2^6 = 64 components
Result: Œ®‚ÇÜ‚ÇÑ ‚àà Spin(12,1) with 64 components
Verification: 8192 / 128 = 64 (Sp(2,‚Ñù) gauge factor = 128)
derivation.comments: This reduction is exact from Clifford algebra representation theory

|Œ®‚ü©_bulk.name: Bulk State
|Œ®‚ü©_bulk.description: Full 26D quantum state entangling all four branes

Tr.name: Partial Trace
Tr.description: Trace over shadow brane degrees of freedom

assumptions: Four identical 4-branes Œ£‚ÇÅ, Œ£‚ÇÇ, Œ£‚ÇÉ, Œ£‚ÇÑ
We observe only Œ£‚ÇÅ (other three are hidden)
Bulk state |Œ®‚ü©_bulk is pure (unitary evolution in 26D)
Tracing over shadow sectors is well-defined
steps: Start: Pure state |Œ®‚ü©_bulk in full 26D Hilbert space
Decomposition: ‚Ñã_bulk = ‚Ñã_Œ£‚ÇÅ ‚äó ‚Ñã_Œ£‚ÇÇ ‚äó ‚Ñã_Œ£‚ÇÉ ‚äó ‚Ñã_Œ£‚ÇÑ
Observable: We measure only on Œ£‚ÇÅ, not on shadow branes
Partial trace: œÅ_Œ£‚ÇÅ = Tr_Œ£‚ÇÇ,Œ£‚ÇÉ,Œ£‚ÇÑ[|Œ®‚ü©‚ü®Œ®|]
Result: œÅ_Œ£‚ÇÅ is generally mixed (even if |Œ®‚ü© is pure)
Interpretation: Apparent randomness from hidden variable (shadow brane state)
Bell evasion: Non-local in 3D, but local in 26D bulk
derivation.comments: This provides geometric origin for quantum hidden variables, evading Bell's theorem via non-locality in extra dimensions

approximations: Assumes shadow branes decouple cleanly (no back-reaction)
Neglects inter-brane interactions beyond bulk Pneuma coupling

hidden-variables.physical_interpretation: What appears as quantum randomness in our observable brane Œ£‚ÇÅ is actually deterministic dynamics in the full 26D bulk. The apparent stochasticity arises because we cannot access the shadow brane states (Œ£‚ÇÇ, Œ£‚ÇÉ, Œ£‚ÇÑ), which serve as hidden variables. This evades Bell's theorem because the correlations are non-local in 3D space but local in the 26D bulk geometry.
hidden-variables.testability: Shadow brane effects may be detectable via: (1) subtle deviations from Born rule probabilities, (2) gravitational signatures from shadow sector mass, (3) KK graviton resonances coupling to shadow branes

division-algebra.label: (3.4) Division Algebra Decomposition

level2_hover.description: 13D as unique combination of division algebra dimensions (Reals, Quaternions, Octonions)

4(‚Ñç).name: Quaternions
4(‚Ñç).description: 4D: Spacetime with Lorentz symmetry SL(2,‚Ñç) ‚âÖ SO(3,1)

8(ùïÜ).name: Octonions
8(ùïÜ).description: 8D: Internal space with exceptional symmetry (G‚ÇÇ automorphism group)

assumptions: Normed division algebras are exactly ‚Ñù, ‚ÑÇ, ‚Ñç, ùïÜ (Hurwitz theorem)
Physical spacetime should be built from division algebras
steps: Hurwitz theorem: Only four normed division algebras exist
‚Ñù (1D): Real numbers - thermal time direction
‚Ñç (4D): Quaternions - 4D spacetime (Penrose twistor theory)
ùïÜ (8D): Octonions - exceptional G‚ÇÇ automorphism group
Total: 1 + 4 + 8 = 13 dimensions
Unique: Only decomposition using all three non-complex division algebras
Cobordism: Œ©‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ^String = 0 (no string anomalies in 13D)
derivation.comments: This explains why D=13 is special: it's the unique sum of all normed division algebra dimensions (excluding ‚ÑÇ)

division-algebra.physical_interpretation: The 13D shadow spacetime has deep algebraic structure. The 1D thermal time corresponds to ‚Ñù, the 4D spacetime to quaternions ‚Ñç (via Penrose twistor theory), and the 8D internal space to octonions ùïÜ (whose automorphism group is G‚ÇÇ). This is the unique way to combine all three non-complex normed division algebras.
